content_scrubbed:
What about people that take out $100k loans to get a CS degree and can't find employment where they live, or the person who takes out $100k in student loans for climate science and just witnessed the entire field in the US get gutted by the president.  What about the doctor who has to take out $250K in loans and wants to work in a lower paying field like Emergency Triage instead of in private practice.  Maybe you should stop thinking that only liberal_arts students are the ones burdened by debt, almost every college student is burdened with debt, some are lucky and get a high paying job in STEM but they are not the majority.

Also expecting an 18 year old with no education on how financial matters work, thanks public education system, to make a financial decision that will impact a huge portion of their adult life is predatory and stupid.  Making a stupid decision to get a bad degree at 18-22 should not make your life a miserable hell for the next 20 years, if you make a stupid purchase on a car you can file for bankruptcy, if you start a business and fail you can go bankrupt, same with everything but medical and student loan debt.  In my opinion two key factors in a functioning society are health and education, if we are making both nearly inaccessible to those without the financial means then we are not a well functioning society.
